results.headline: Stumbling Through Hazy Days of Winter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Goes Up

results.summary_short: There’s some nice filmmaking tucked inside “What Goes Up,” a muddle of moods and intentions.

results.headline: The House That Soared

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Up

results.summary_short: In its opening stretch the new Pixar movie “Up” flies high, borne aloft by a sense of creative flight and a flawlessly realized love story.

results.headline: A Surprise Is in Store for This Shock Jock

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pontypool

results.summary_short: “Pontypool” is a small Canadian horror film that makes the most of its minuscule budget.

results.headline: Making a Living Handling Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Departures

results.summary_short: “Departures” is overlong, predictable in its plotting and utterly banal in its blending of comic whimsy and melodramatic pathos.

results.headline: Navigating Ramallah, an Eye Out for the Absurd

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Laila's Birthday

results.summary_short: Rashid Masharawi’s film is a fleet, dark urban comedy that registers outrage in glancing jabs of absurdist observation.

results.headline: Putting Inspiration on the Front Burner

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pressure Cooker

results.summary_short: “Pressure Cooker” belongs to the honorable genre of inspirational films dedicated to the proposition that one passionate teacher can make a difference in the lives of students.

results.headline: Marry in Haste, Repent at Decaying Castle With Possessive Mater

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Easy Virtue

results.summary_short: In its cold-eyed assessment of the English aristocracy “Easy Virtue” has none of the lurking Anglophilia found in Merchant-Ivory movies.

results.headline: Imperialistic Ambition Affecting Ordinary Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kabei: Our Mother

results.summary_short: “Kabei: Our Mother” is a soapy immersion in the tribulations of a Tokyo wife and mother facing World War II.

results.headline: Bigotry and Xenophobia in 1950s America

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghosts of the Heartland

results.summary_short: “Ghosts of the Heartland” might have been more effective with a little more honey and a lot less vinegar.

results.headline: A Family Affair, Dysfunction Included
results.display_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story

results.summary_short: “The Boys” is an irresistible documentary about the inexhaustible sibling songwriting duo Richard and Robert Sherman.

results.headline: Conspiracy Theorists Examined

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New World Order

results.summary_short: “New World Order” is an unrelentingly tedious documentary.

results.headline: Dad’s at Another Museum. Does That Make Him an Exhibitionist?
results.display_title: Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian

results.summary_short: The paradox of “Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian” is that a movie so bursting with novelty can feel so utterly familiar.

results.headline: Off His Train, the Engineer Is Derailed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of O'Horten

results.summary_short: “O’Horten” is made up of meticulously constructed, deadpan scenes that turn on Keatonesque visual jokes.

results.headline: Artist With His Signature on the City
results.display_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight

results.summary_short: “To Inform & Delight” may leave you with the impression that the spirit of modern New York was conjured out of thin air by its subject.

results.headline: ’Tis Pity She’s a Brand

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girlfriend Experience

results.summary_short: “The Girlfriend Experience” has a sleek, tailored look appropriate to its setting, which is the moneyed precincts of Manhattan at the height of the recent gilded age.

results.headline: Step Up but Stand Clear of the Guy in the Fat Suit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dance Flick

results.summary_short: The belly laughs in “Dance Flick” leave you feeling liberated and not guilty.

results.headline: Heavy Metal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terminator Salvation

results.summary_short: “Terminator Salvation” feels both comfortable with its limitations and justly proud of its accomplishments.

results.headline: Bravery Fills Secret Burmese Dispatches

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burma VJ

results.summary_short: “Burma VJ” is a rich, thought-provoking film not only because of the story it tells, but also because of the perspective it offers.

results.headline: Sorting Out an Inheritance: Three Siblings Dissect the Stuff of Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer Hours

results.summary_short: “Summer Hours,” in spite of its potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication.

results.headline: Monster Mash-Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Man Japan

results.summary_short: The revisionist superhero trend takes a quizzical turn in “Big Man Japan,” a deadpan mockumentary with a lively sense of the perverse.
